definition[0]: a feeling of great respect and liking for something or someone
example[0]: Daniel gazed at her in admiration.
example[1]: I wanted to express my admiration for the way the crew handled the crisis.
example[2]: Her riding soon drew the admiration of the older girls.
example[3]: He’s a man for whom I have the greatest admiration.
example[4]: She had a deep admiration for the work of Russian writers.
example[5]: Bacon had often expressed his profound admiration for Picasso’s paintings.
example[6]: ‘Where did you learn to do that?’ she asked with genuine admiration.
example[7]: I have always had a sneaking admiration for his music.
example[8]: Her father looked at her in open admiration.
example[9]: There was grudging admiration in his voice.
example[10]: Their friendship was based on mutual admiration.
collocation[7]: be full of admiration/be filled with admiration
example[11]: I’m full of admiration for what you’ve done.
collocation[8]: have nothing but admiration for somebody
example[12]: I have nothing but admiration for his work.
collocation[9]: have great/deep/a lot of etc admiration
example[13]: She always had great admiration for people who could speak so many languages.
example[14]: His films have won the admiration of the critics.
example[15]: At the club, her singing soon drew the admiration of the older girls.
example[16]: She wrote to him expressing her admiration for his work.
example[17]: I wanted to show my admiration for what he had done.
